caption: Table 1: Cumulative regret of bandit-based methods on online link prediction.
description: This table presents the cumulative regret values achieved by various bandit-based methods (EE-Net, NeuGreedy, NeuralUCB, NeuralTS, and PRB) on four different online link prediction datasets (MovieLens, AmazonFashion, Facebook, and GrQc).  Lower cumulative regret indicates better performance. The results demonstrate the performance of the proposed method (PRB) compared to the baseline methods. The mean and standard deviation of cumulative regret across 10 runs are reported for each method.

caption: Table 2: Cumulative regret of bandit-based methods on online node classification.
description: This table presents the cumulative regret results for various bandit-based methods (EE-Net, NeuGreedy, NeuralUCB, NeuralTS) and the proposed PRB method on three online node classification datasets (Cora, Citeseer, and Pubmed).  The lower the cumulative regret, the better the performance of the method. The mean and standard deviation of the cumulative regret are shown for each method across multiple runs.

caption: Table 3: Results on offline link prediction benchmarks. OOM means out of GPU memory.
description: This table presents the results of offline link prediction experiments comparing PRB against several graph-based baselines across six datasets.  The results are reported using the Hits@k metric.  The table shows that PRB achieves consistently better performance than all other methods across all datasets. OOM denotes that the method ran out of GPU memory.

caption: Table 1: Cumulative regret of bandit-based methods on online link prediction.
description: This table presents the cumulative regret of various bandit-based methods (EE-Net, NeuGreedy, NeuralUCB, NeuralTS, and PRB) on four different online link prediction datasets (MovieLens, AmazonFashion, Facebook, and GrQc).  The cumulative regret is a measure of the algorithm's performance, with lower values indicating better performance. The results show PRB's consistent outperformance of other methods across all datasets.

caption: Table 1: Cumulative regret of bandit-based methods on online link prediction.
description: This table presents the cumulative regret of several bandit-based methods for online link prediction on four datasets: MovieLens, Amazon Fashion, Facebook, and GrQc. The methods compared include EE-Net, NeuGreedy, NeuralUCB, NeuralTS, and PRB.  Lower values indicate better performance, reflecting a smaller cumulative difference between the algorithm's choices and those of an optimal predictor.  The standard deviation is also provided.

caption: Table 3: Results on offline link prediction benchmarks. OOM means out of GPU memory.
description: This table presents the results of offline link prediction experiments, comparing the proposed PRB method against several graph-based baselines across six datasets.  The results are measured using the Hits@100 metric, which represents the accuracy of link prediction.  The table shows that PRB generally outperforms the existing methods, particularly on the Collab, PPA, and DDI datasets.  OOM indicates that a method ran out of GPU memory and thus could not complete the experiment.

caption: Table 1: Cumulative regret of bandit-based methods on online link prediction.
description: This table presents the cumulative regret values achieved by different bandit-based methods (EE-Net, NeuGreedy, NeuralUCB, NeuralTS, and PRB) on four online link prediction datasets (MovieLens, AmazonFashion, Facebook, and GrQc).  The cumulative regret is a metric that evaluates the algorithm's performance in sequentially making link predictions and aims to measure how far the algorithm's performance is from the optimal strategy. A lower cumulative regret indicates better performance.
